properties.media:imagetext:
N. Y. March 6th
1958
Dear Girlst.
I
came up here for a meting of PAA on the 4th and
an staying
over for
a meeting of GPU on the 10th - meanwhile engaging in that pleasant
task which
Uncle San reserves for his nephews of making out my income tax.
In my odd moments will try to give you a brief
run down on our
recent trip
around So. America.
The Director's flight left N.Y.
on the
7th of Feb. with the first stop Havana where Ma and I joined
them. We left
there on the 9th and
after a four hour flight arrived at Curacoa in the
Dutch B West Indies.
There PAA built a most attractive hotel on the founda-
tion of an old fort which guarded the entrance to the harbor.
It was sunday
but they kept the stores open to the delight of the women and dismay of the
men on
the trip. On the 10th we made a 72 hour flight across Columbia and a
part of Venzuela to Lima, Peru.
to Cuzco in a Panagra D03.
The next morning some of our party flew up
and of course
Pa an unpressurized tene ve a to have ye ero this van es
supplied through outlets at each seat and we all wore masks -
looking for all
the world like a lot of horses at chow time.
Some
of the
party did not go
To tell
the truth I
was too but didn't say
about it.
Reminded me of old man
Ball when he took delivery of his first airplane he told the pilot to climb
to 10,000 feet.
The pilot objected because
they had to make El
Paso before
dark but Mr. Ball insisted.
The pilot climbed up to 10,000 and coasted on in
to El Paso.
There he asked again why the old man insisted and Mr.
Ball
said
"I
dont mind telling you now.
The doctor said if I went up to 7,500 feet
that I would drop dead so I just spotted him 2,500
feet to
prove that he did
not know what the H
he was talking about."
We loved Cuzco
and neither of
us felt the altitude at all.
Of course the thing that interested me most was
the stone walls that the old Incas built.
Some of the
stones weigh 20 or
30,000 lbs. were moved as much as a mile and
are so close together that you
cant put a knife blade between them at any point of the 7 foot joint.
This
they did without steel chisels - no
one knows just how. We stayed
overnight
and the next morning flew back to Lima.
On the 13th we flew 7 hours along
the coast of Peru and Chili with the unending blue Pacific on our right and
the snow capped Andes on the left.
It was a magnificent flight.
We
spent
that night and the next in Santiago and on the 15th flew over the highest
mountain in this hemisphere and then circled
down in a valley to 15,000 feet
where we had a good look at the Christ of the Andes.
After about three hours
we landed at Bariloche in the Chilean Lake country.
Actually we were just
over
the Chilean border in Argentina some 450 miles south and
west of B.A.
The lake was sonething like Lake George - the water as blue - but the mount-
ains all around
and mostly snow capped.
of course in their
ves rese At the rattle hotel where we stayed ave
We were there
sumner.
Trippe
had us all in a little room off the bar for drinks before dinner.
Someone
tapped me on
the shoulder and when I
turned around
there was wes
Shapleigh.
The Ss,
Danforths,
Stuarts and Whitesides all old friends from St. Louis
were on a trip around
South America.
It was as though you'd
run into an old
friend at Lake Pharoah.. Frank Gledhill
and I
got up
early the next morning
and went fishing.
We were only out about an hour but he caught an 8 lb.
rainbow trout.
We had lunch at a private home on the edge of the lake which
